content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Oh how I was missing this game of my account...After the last SimCity... Mess? I honestly forgot how amazing the previous SimCity games were! I used to play SimCity 3000 UK but I've never played SimCity 4. Although this is a bit dated now, it is still amazing, the landscaping works really well, the roads, tracks, motorways etc work nicely and the buildings and structures are pretty nice models seems this game states it was released in 2003.The graphics are good, Obviously a little dated but... You'd know that, the only thing I wish it had in video settings was 1080p. [ READ BELOW ]-- UPDATE: Thanks to user "Damon Gant", you can go to 1080p easily, you need to go into "Launch Options" and type / copy & paste "-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32". Works brilliantly, Icons are a little small but still clear.One extra little thing I liked was the ability to play as a Sim inside your city... Driving a car, truck, boat, helicopter andplane... This doesn't seem to add anything useful to the game but it's a nice feature to have!Only things I don't like about this game are the fact that bridges can't go diagonal and the building zones can't go diagonal.I think this game is near-perfect, Noticed no bugs, glitches, freezes or crashes. I'd also imagine that majority of people can play this as it isn't a demanding game.This is now my favourite City building game, It was CitiesXL but that game has annoying bugs etc.-- Side note after playing a couple hours. You'll need to save your game every so often, this game does crash.. Probably an issue with Windows 7? No Idea! - This isn't a huge issue aslong as you remember to save!

												Mac version not recommended.  It was clearly an afterthought and even simple features such as importing heightmaps or custom regions are not supported.  Most mods will not work.Gameplay in general is enjoyable but not as engrossing as I remember classic Sim City being.  U Drive It missions are terrible.  The interface is clunky and slow to respond, and while you're trying to learn how to drive thrings around your city your failed missions cause you to lose money, reputation and sometimes even city features.For the price I can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												SimCity…The definitive city building game…The time show on steam doesn’t show the amount of time I have spent since I bought the game in 2004. As a matter of fact, I have gone through about 5 copies of this game…SimCity4 has infinite replay value. No 2 cities will be the same…..don’t even attempt to make a duplicate city…it will not work.Simcity4 works a little differently from the previous version of SimCity in that, where the previous versions just gave you a plot of land to build on, SC4 lets you select a region, akin to a city or county in your state. You can import and export among the regions, sell electricity, water and import garbage. Build a police station with a helipad and be a helicopter pilot stopping crimes. Build a hospital with a helipad, and deliver a liver for a transplant. Build a small airfield and  spray crops for insects, or write messages in the sky. Built an airport, and watch the tourism tax dollars start rolling in…

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I have had 500+ hours playing this gem-of-a-game which is, in my opinion,the best city-building game till date ! The fun that one gets by starting from scratch by building farms to enjoying those moments when the first skyscraper starts growing up is amazing . The depth this game has in terms of buildings and strategy  is what has made this game what it is .             From different varieties of powerplants,parks,playgrounds to the variety in roads,highways,transportation system,this game lacks none ! And the most amazing part is that,you also get to drive vehicles in your city  and see for yourself how pathetic or awesome your city traffic and roads are :)             I really wish there is another SimCity which comes out better than this,but till then , SimCity 4 :Rush Hour will live on \m/

content:
Posted: February 11
												What do I have to say of this game? Sadly, modern day computers have some issues running this... but I can safely say this game had some great childhood memories for me when I had it on a phyiscal copy. I'd say, if you have an older computer that runs on Windows 2000, XP or Vista, definitely run SC4 on this.Even with the complaint of newer computers not running the game very well, I would really recommend playing this since it's the best SimCity game of the series and you will have fun for hours building small towns to huge cities all you imagine. You can even import your small SimCity 4 maps into The Sims 2. Also fun for those who want their custom made maps in there. :3

content:
Posted: February 22, 2012
												This is the most elite example of "Dumbed Down for the Console ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;.  Simcity 3000 is better.  Simcity 2000 is better!.  By sacraficeing a massive amount of actual customizeability and gutting most of what makes SimCity fun to use, they make a game that is more appealing to causal gamers.  The terrain editor is a joke by not giving you precice control like the editor in Simcity 2000 and the way the zoning system adds in "Streets" Guts the actual customizeability and haveing 6 different roads that do the SAME THING is the most useless thing I've ever seen, they switched a pathetic power plant selection to have 10 different mass transit systems you will never NEED because they space the occupy traded by the paltry city size.  And why are there only two options for city size!? the "Large" city in this game feels smaller than the max city size in simcity 2000!This is a Terrible game, do not waste your money on it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Ahhh, SimCity. We have played every version up to 4. Still the reliable and comforting game we knew. Our Current Computer SpecsWindows 7 Home Premium using "SERCIVE PACK 1" (Auto update disabled)Hewlett-Packard HP Pavilion g7 Notebook PCAMD Processor A6-3420M APU with Radeon HD Graphics 1.50 GHzRAM 8.00 GB (3.48 usable)64-bit Operating SystemWe have not had any issues w/ the game for any reason. No stuttering or lagging. This game doesn't have the most fanciest graphics, but you have to remember it was made for Windows XP. The price tag at 19.99 is a little high. We suggest waiting until it is below the 10.00 mark.Out of 10 we give this game an 8. Relaxing, nobody shooting at you. Just a game to waste a few hours on kicked back having a drink.Enjoy.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Straight up classic. Was the premier title in its genre for over a decade until cities skylines came along, but it is still great. My experience with the game is pre steam, and I still have the disk. Base gameplay is reasonably complex with a multitude of options, if some of the simulation is simplified becasuse of the technical limitations of its day. Has a dash of humor for good measure. Reasonable difficulty once you understand how the game works. There are a few technical issues on newer operating systems, but fixes exist if you google for them.OH, almost forgot about the insane amount of mods for this. You can find anything you could possibly want for the game online.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												This game may be old, but this I think is it's saving grace. It's moddable beyond anything a modern games maker would even consider, letting you change traffic simulation, train, plane and ferry skins, add buildings, add HD textures, alter the way a city needs to grow, you name it. And installation of said mods is child's play, simply downloading files into a plugin folder. And because of it's age the sheer amount of mods out there is insane. The community is still alive and kicking after 11 years, which tells you something about the longevity of this game. If you like city builders then look no further, Maxis set the bar with this one and it has yet to be beaten.

												It's Sim City, on Steam. Forget the woes of the recent re-launch - Sim City 4 is just about all you need. While not as visually flashy as modern city-builders, it's got the most features and some would say the most fun. It can generally be purchased incredibly cheaply during Steam sales, definitely worth a buy to relive the Sim City nostalgia of old, or for totally new players.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												This is IT!This game is the Holy grail of city simulation. You can search for other city sims, but there is none worthy of this one.Sure you have the new ''city sims''. But those are games. Maybe they are playable, maybe they have good graphics, maybe they have a satisfactory sim engine. But nothing beats SC4. Nothing can even compare to the vastness of this beauty! The only reason I got a Steam account is to buy this game again. After you get a hang of it, you will be able to build vast cities. And I don't mean vast simcity 2013 stuffthatisntreallyevenbig, I mean real life vast. You can make a city over an infinite amount of tiles. and the tiles are 4x4km, so that is vast. You can make complex networks of roads, rails, waterways, highways, canals.. bassically anything you can think of. Due to the again VAST online community of modders, who after 10 years still make new and new stuff every day!And when I say that, that means free and for the more organised teams thoroughly coded, tested and fully functional mods, that have changed the game to an extent, that it became unrecognasible. And all that from people that live for this game, not some employees of some big company doing stuff they are dictated to do as quick and buggy as possible.If you like the genre of city simulation. You can not buy a better game. And the amount of money spent on this game, is money well spent!To a 10 more years of Sim City 4!

Posted: December 22, 2013
												This game takes a bit of reading and youtube to learn, but, once you get the hang of it, it will bring you many hours of entertainment. Remember resources in other cities can transfer over, so you can make an entire city a landfill! I think that is really fun to do. Since you are god you can also ruin the lives of your citizens by setting fires, tornados, meteors, volcanos, aliens, giant robots, and more! If this game goes $10 or less it is worth the investment.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2013
												Probably the best city building, management and simulator ever made. Extremely detailed, with lots and lots of well done prerendered graphics (the world, cars and some objects are 3D though, so it doesn't ruin the presentation at all). It's the deepest SimCity, and it's also the hardest: you'll really need to grow your city slowly and watch the taxes, or else you'll be bankrupt in no time. But if you're patient, you'll be rewarded with hours and hours of fun. It's good to be the Mayor!There are some problems though. For example, no widescreen support and flawed transit (both can be fixed by mods). Also the game has some compatibility issues with newer systems and 64 bit Windows, so you'll have to use software mode and put some graphics options on medium and low.Other small flaws are: the driving minigames (you can drive cars, helicopters, planes and even a tank on missions around the city), which are a bit annoying, and can become frustrating due to city traffic and sudden failures. Nowhere near as good as what Streets of SImCity did with SC2000's maps. And the other small problem is that  it tries to mimic the graphic style of The Sims, so most cities will look the same. Still, it's good that they didn't casualize the game to the max back then in 2003, trying to appeal to The Sims audience. Instead, we got the most complex SimCity to date, and I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												What a city simulator needs to be. No major issues with Steam version, tweaks work what I've tested, even uses Windows Documents folder to seek for plug-ins and stuff. Plenty of support, ideas, mods and what not from various internet sources. Prefers Intel processors though, used to crash regularily on my old AMD dual core way back then.Much recommended, regardless of its age, possibly the only city simulator ever truly worth it.EDIT: Further study revealed that the issue with crashing or sudden abortions of the game was and remains to be mainly use of multi core CPUs, not so much of the make itself. Therefore it's advisable to set the SC4's CPU affinity to single core only which significantly reduces the infamous occurences of game aborting to desktop in a zap. Still, keep saving the game progress frequently, especially before and after all major building or city tweaking sessions. Google for further details on how to set CPU affinity or to modify Steam's game start settings.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2012
												A all-time classic in my world and ten years later, still utterly playable.  Recommended to all those with cravings to literally make a perfect world for us all to live.  It's odd though, no matter what I 'tweak' this game runs choppy and seems only fit for CPU's under 2 cores and older school graphic cards (Nvidia 7 series and older), but still works OK-ish.Somehow for me, it works better in software mode (which means my Gfx card isn't used at all) but doesn't look 100%, but a lot more playable.  I guess a single core on my 8 core system works better than a my Gfx cards GPU's and cores.Why have suddenly started playing this again?  SimCity, the (2012) new release has officially been annouced by Maxis and EA... finally after ten years, it's getting it much deserve update.  A game I truly and officially want, now... as well as GTA:5, HL:3 and L4D3 []^_^]

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Edited from original. It's a simulator, the fun thing with simulators is you say when you have won or lost. It's something you have to look at a lot and maybe tweak and adjust or tear down and start again. I cannot express this enough, you set your goal in the region you want and work towards it. Or you find a region and see how it develops where you and the residents work together to make something you can both work with and look at for hours and hours. Because it did draw hours and hours trying to see how the game worked, where the balances where. And that was why we played them.Sounds abit shouty, but its how I play and is this is valid to you. I do want you to enjoy this game as much i have as.In a nutshell. It's an old game, I think you need to tweak win10, and maybe some resolution.I play Mac, no issues with 10.10.3 on late 2008 macbook.The rushhour is needed imho to see how commutes work.Communities external to steam still there at Jan 2016.Great to revisit and send a tornado through Bob Newbies back yard.. Bad arm was it Bob?Part of the original.If your rig can't run the all new fancy city builders, or you distrust the 'always on' DRM management style, this is great.10/10 will laugh at children playing city management games again.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												SC Deluxe is the pinnacle of City-Builders to date, offering a complex city simulation and a steep learning curve unlike any other. The game tutorials introduce you to the core mechanics and an overview of how to balance your finances with your cities growth, and then allows you to develop the neighbouring cities into fledgling cities. Once you have accomplished this feat, the game offers various other famous locations to build your metropolises from scratch.Although the game suffers dated graphics, the gameplay is definately not. My only suggestion is that if you do buy Simcity 4 Deluxe, ensure you visit the modding community, who have poured years into the various mods which not only increase city variation, but offer complete rewrites of various features (Such as NAM, a transport network mod which offers unprecedented levels of control of how your city traffic flows, and how it appears)

Then again, SimCity 4 doesn't require an Internet Connection to actually play the game or a separate Origin account (Elecronic Arts, be damned!), so I'll still say it's better than it's successor.

Posted: May 18, 2012
												If you havent played a SimCity game by now you probably never will.  I do enjoy them.  They are games that aren't just for people who play video games.  Its interesting to watch your city, you designed, grow.  The only difference in the sequels is mainly the details.  You get more land and has more detailed graphics.  This one lets you connect citys on a much larger map.  I think it even lets you connect to other peoples cities.  I like these games but i dont think this is worth more than 10 bucks.  I never pay much for my games.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Be the mayor of your own city!Sim City 4 offers many things to build and create your very own city, especially with the Add-On "Rush Hour". Connect your city with other cities in your region, trade and let your city grow to a metropole. Of course, it takes time to get all the nice things but it's a nice challenge, with pleasant graphics, relaxing music and some little tasks to improve your reputation.If you like simulations and wish create the city of your dreams, without going to war, Sim City 4 is a classic.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Time has passed but this game hasn't aged that much. It's a solid fun game, friendly to kids and adults as well, where you cause your own troubles in your city, and for this cutting-edge graphics aren't a priority. Even more than ten years later, the basics for city building games hasn't changed. What excites me most in SimCity 4 is doubtless the Rush Hour, where you can see the traffic in your city and makes you plan your design more carefully, combining different modes of transport and thinking about city population density. Give it a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Very classic SimCity game. A graphically and gameplay-wise updated version of the original SimCity2000 style game. Connecting your cities through the regional map is fun and entertaining. Allowing transport and trade between the cities also adds another layer of depth to the game. I can spend hours at a time making new cities, and after all the work it's very satisfying to see a full region. Not much to conplain about, any annoying features of the game (like fires or pipebursts) can be avoided by playing properly.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												An Amazing Game got over 212hours 36min in the game in less than 2 months, thats how addicted I am! Although I had some technical issues with the game crashing and refusing to start (which I nedded to delte my saved data to get the game to start) but with some tinkering around with the files and downloading the SC4 launcher it runs. The gameplay is amazing easy to learn hard to master the zoneing, Road networks, services, and teriforming tools work smoothly and intuitive. However, how come the soundtrack is soo good I could listen for hours. If there is one problem with the game it would be the traffic system. Traffic is to much of an issue and it can destroy your city, with buildings be abandoned left right and centre, and the mass transit is hard to manage. Even if I set ordnaces and toll boths to encourage it next to nobody use it! Also another small gripe I have is the railway you have to make the track in certain ways and you can't just do a simple turn like with roads you have to do a weird curve system for it to work  and they are impossible to maage the swichers and stations. It just so frustrating!! for example to make a railway system to function I nedded to demolish around 10 houses and it was really costily, and even after all my work, nobody used it! Sorry those unlucky souls that lost there homes in the great awful railway purge of 2003. And don't get med started on regoinal traffic, Ha Ha Ha Maxis I will end you. Anyway despite these issues it is an extraodinary game and is timeless it puts SimCity 5/2013 to shame! and the traffic issues I mentioned can be solved with mods (which I have installed) but I am judjing this game on its own merits.I give this game a 8/10 (Very Good)

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												After playing simcity 2000, and 3000, this is just what I expected. Another step up.It's takes a while to get use to the new system, but once you have it, this is a really great simcity game to play.The driving games are not as great as I wanted, but are still a nice addition, even if a little buggy with car AIs.Cars run right into intersections and sometimes ram you when your sirens are on, and can spawn out of no where.If you have a newer PC, don't play this. It's not built for them. Mine crashes rarely. I run a dual core with vista and Ge Force go 7400.It has it's flaws, but if you love simcity, and think your computer isn't too new for it, then I definitely recommend playing this!  If your computer is rather new, maybe try running it on a virtual machine?Oh, and the tutorial made me place the filthiest power plant in sim reigen right next to my residential zone.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												After playing simcity 2000, and 3000, this is just what I expected. Another step up.It's takes a while to get use to the new system, but once you have it, this is a really great simcity game to play.The driving games are not as great as I wanted, but are still a nice addition, even if a little buggy with car AIs.Cars run right into intersections and sometimes ram you when your sirens are on, and can spawn out of no where.If you have a newer PC, don't play this. It's not built for them. Mine crashes rarely. I run a dual core with vista and Ge Force go 7400.It has it's flaws, but if you love simcity, and think your computer isn't too new for it, then I definitely recommend playing this!  If your computer is rather new, maybe try running it on a virtual machine?Oh, and the tutorial made me place the filthiest power plant in sim reigen right next to my residential zone.

												This game is wonderful. It sadly, however, wont work on my new computer. Anyway, it is wonderful because you can create a city and you have COMPLETE POWER! There is NO democracy, literally. It's like you've got a dictatorship city. The only thing stopping you from having the Sphinx as your first building is money. Money is required for everything. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												One of the best games I've ever played, so much fun.Btw. some people tell you you have to mod it like shity skylines to make it playable and fun but to be honest all you need are two more hospitals and you are good to go. Also since you have the deluce version which has the rushhour addoon in it you can play it with smaller cpus if I remember correctly. Because the original version if you had a lack of cpu power it would let the whole trafic flow over one route which is just anoying. But who still has such a smal cpu? Also you should write special start conditions in the header of this file, just google it and you know what I mean, to play it in HD. You can also play it in 4K but except that the menus are rediclius smal your pc will not make it. Seriously everything is rendered with the CPU, it is an old game. You need a 500€ cpu and you might be able to do that.Anyway let's cut the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t I could rant over so much about this game the whole time but seriously just play this game if you look for a serious chalange. Actually you can outmaneuver the game and just make a big city without anything but hightech industry, no smoke yeaaah!.^^ But if you want it more easy play shity skylinies or shities xxl.If you are not familier with the simcity serious I am telling you play 3000 first, but where to get it, and where is an installer for modern PCs? I was able to install it back with win7 but win10 doesn't work and it has allot of problem which is sad because simcity 3000 is one of the cutest and funniest city builder which you still can consider serious.So play simcity 2000 instead and when you are back and just outplayed this game (*cough* just crank the taxes up to 8 *cough*) and than come back and play this one, it can be tough as nails but after a 100 hours you have a natural flow and just do it without thinking about it. Yeah I gues I am one of the few ones who may plaed 1000hours of this game but that was way back in the 00th years. But I can guarantee you 100 hours of fun.And I want to mentioned I loved this game even we where a little disapointed that it wasn't full 3D.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												After a 20 year break, I figured this summer it would be a good time to get back into the SimCIty franchise with 2003's SimCity 4.This is one of those games where its greatest strength happens to also be its greatest weakness. The game is incredibly deep, which to a SimCity enthusiast must be the ultimate dream. For entry level players it is however a substantial barrier to entry. There is a tutorial, although I felt it could have been a little more in depth beyond the basics it does go over.But once you are rolling, you are in command of all the tools you'll ever need to run your city. If you're like me, you'll become attached to your city as its very own life-form, and will want to nurture it along in its development. And since this is an 8 year old title, it was a nice surprise to have a game today that isn't innundated with achievements and ceaseless updates.SimCity 4 is a winner, I'm glad I made the trip back im gaming time to play it.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Low Frame Rates- My computer can run games like Half-Life 2 and Tropico 5 no problem, this game however (even with being a game from 2004) can't get above 4 frames-per-second.Broken Engine - You need to save every minute due to the fact that it will *inevitably* crash and erase all your work since you last saved.Broken Funding- The funding mechanics are prone to braking. For instance I have had tens of cities in which hospitals, schools etc, ask for more funding, even though the funding was as high as I could possibly set it.For a tenner it's a pretty decent game which has brought me hundreds of hours of time wasting fun, however it's too broken and buggy to recomend to anyone I'm afraid.

												This game was released in 2003. It is unstable in Windows 10. The settings menu do not include the option to set the resolution to 1080.To get the resolution to 1080 you have to use this command in launch options (Thanks lesnoobz):-CustomResolution:enabled -r1920x1080x32 -fThe game itself is not so bad if you manage to make it playable, but it is likely you will still get bored after a few hours. It lacks something that made the previous versions fun.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Why do I feel like this game slaps me silly for trying to build a city the way I want rather than their railroaded formula? What fun is it playing the same exact city over and over again? I want there to be a police station right off the bat... nope costs too much.... and the game literally tells you NOT to build a fire station until you have your first fire. By that logic, it makes sense build and raze them after each emergency.The driving mini game is horrible. Cars vanish and appear while your driving making cars you were going to crash into vanish while the opening you did have is now magically occupied.I have tried playing this game. I have forced myself to play it telling myself it'd get better but it hasn't. Honestly if I was offered my money back for it. I'd take it. The only reason why I bought this game was because I loved SimCity2000 as a child (which is no longer compatible with windows no matter how hard I try). I hoped to reclaim the joy of my childhood. Instead I listen to a bunch of sims all screaming about how badly I'm doing OR I finally get the balence right and make a meager $200.00 a month.

												I previously played a game of sim city on my old sony ericsson phone years ago and thought it was a lot of fun, it was click and point with good graphics arguably better than this game. Further too this the games graphics are all over the place, I have read this is because of my modern computer, the solutions offered as well are too complicated for someone who knows little about computers. If like me you know little about computers, I would avoid this game, especially if you are using a modern computer. I am now going to investigate if there is a sim city that can be bought that is similar to the phone version I had, much more user friendly.

number of helpful: 24 of 63 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Unintuitive, clunky, poor interface, boring, lack of personality, just plain not fun. Any one of these things would spell the death knoll for a game, but SimCity nails them all. To make matters even worse, it doesn't like windows 7 or 8, and will fight you to the death on anything past XP. And it will win.See, the sad part here is I actually *LIKE* city-builder games. Tycoon series? Pretty good! Tropico 4? Awesome! SimCity 1? Win. Afterlife? Epix Win. Sim City 4? Eh... mediocre at best?So what went wrong? How did SC4 fail it up so badly?I think the biggest problem was they lost sight of what made sim city games fun... the city building and the balancing of economy against people's desires. These things all exist in Sim City, and they've been inflated to a status of excessive grandeur, but that may be where the problem is: too much of a good thing.Yes, there's lots of buildings, tons of them in fact... but it mostly just turns into a bogged down mess of junk to sort through if you want to have even a minimally running city at all. Instead of having a reasonable juggling act of a few major things your people need to be happy, tempered by a limited economy, Sim City 4 just throws all caution to the wind and piles on heaps of useless busywork. It's not even interesting construction; a good chunk of it's underground where you'll never even see it anyway. It's just there to waste money and make building the city more "realistic" but less interesting.If I wanted "real" I wouldn't be playing a game.Tropico 4... is a nice balance. It tosses the balls at you one at a time, slowly ramping up the difficulty and keeping the game entertaining and interesting the whole way. Sim City 4 piles too much needless crap on all at once that provides a remarkably harsh learning curve, for a minimal reward at the end.Sim games have typically struck a wonderful balance in the past between the work and reward aspects, and gave you the tools needed to quickly and efficiently manage your little slice of heaven (or both heaven and hell if playing afterlife =P ). SC4 just kinda drops the ball (to maintain the juggling metaphor from the previous paragraph) by giving slow, irritating, clunky tools which technically "get the job done", but are a pain to use and not very fun.Toss in the severe glitches, and absolute, seething hatred SC4 has for pretty much anything above WinXP, and you may as well not even bother considering it. There's simply better games out there... Cities XL for the obsessive compulsive "realistic" city builder, Tropico 4 for those who want a great storyline and awesome gameplay with proper balance of being "just right" a la goldilocks... and afterlife or sim city classic if you're nostalgic.Final Verdict:SC4 really just doesn't have a place in the city builder market. Anything it does, other games do better. Much, much better. Game-breaking glitches don't help it's argument, either.Overall Score: About 40%. If you can get it to run, it's not really BAD... it's just not particularly good, and you can do better for lower cost, anyway. The music's pretty epic, though.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												             This game used to be very fun to play even on low end computers, and I have only recently found the perfect most quickest way to build a very large city at a fast pace (without the cheats). Yet after two occurences already I have found SimCity 4 lacks a very useful tool that most games actually have and is very useful for those "on a roll" so to speak and has little time to think about 'saving' the f'ing game this "tool" is known to many as, bear with me now, AUTO-SAVE. What?! How?! Oh My God?! Yes I know what your thinking, and I know this will never be implemented into this 12 year old game so i've given up.              Since SC4 dislikes the player actually doing good in a game and/or working hard while having fun making the best god damn city man has ever seen! i.e. SimCity 4 says: BEGONE UNHOLY CREATURE FOR YOU HAVE, uh... CORRUPTED THIS LAND WITH YOUR FILTHY HARMONIOUS AND HIGHLY EFFICIENT CITY WITH A GREAT MANY THOUSANDS OF INHABITANTS THAT YOU HAVE WORKED ON FOR NEARLY 3 HOURS! screw it ill just be a♥♥♥♥♥♥and crash now....again."Just like that every time i get to a certain point. Unfortunately that pisses me off and so I now hate this game because I have wasted 3+ hours twice now and to me that is VERY valuable. Thus ♥♥♥♥ you S C 4! I mean Thank you for reading.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game will be out dated by the time you get a display that uses 16:9 aspect ratio, which for most people was 7 years ago.You can only build roads at 90 and 45 degrees, and only straight roads, so that significantly limits what you can do with a city.You don't really get to choose what types of businesses you want... only the zone type.  This is done to make the game linear... start as a poor farm town, upgrade to a suburb, upgrade to a city.I just couldn't get into it.  I kept wanting to micro manage the details of the city, and the game just isn't designed for that.

number of helpful: 1 of 13 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												I can't believe how many people gave this game positive reviews.  It looks NOTHING LIKE the game depicted in the images.  The graphics are halfway to terrible, and the usability is in the toilet.  I messed with it for two hours, and finally decided it just couldn't be worth it.  I spent twenty minutes trying to make a highway, and none of the pieces would connect, no matter what I did about on-ramps and ground-this and clover-leafs-that.  I even went through half of the tutorials before I played.  Worse than this is how often you build an area that builds itself streets that aren't connected to existing streets or builds plots that can't access a road.  And can you just bulldoze them?  No.  I also wasted fifteen minutes trying to make the land appropriate for a beach—seriously?  Why not have the beach auto-teraform if you're going to make it so picky?  Add in the screaming idiot always calling to you to try his stupid roadway adventure (i.e., boring arrow-tapping exercise), and you have an intolerable game.  I'm so disappointed.Who wrote these other reviews?  Everyone made it sound like we finally had a proper Sim City game again.  I hate to say it, but we just don't.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												What a dreadful let down. OK, I'm only ten years too late to this game, but I remember the good old days, OK? I thought I'd do some catching up.The region view is a waste of time. Literally. You can't do anything there, and your cities don't talk to one another once they are up and running. There's even still a graphical glitch on some cards.Get into the game and you are plagued by constant pop ups, to the point where you cannot concentrate on being a mayor for ordering fire engines to put out fires. The minute you start placeing government buildings like schools all your staff start striking.The easiest way to progress and have a working city is to use lots of low density zones, power them with wind and water them with towers, have no agriculture, no public buildings, no transport or utilities. Your scumbag city will sit there and generate a nice wee income and you can tinker at the edges.But try and build a thriving metropolis and be prepared to be bothered out of your wits by endless advisors.For a slice of old school Sim City try the iPad version. Much better.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I used to love SimCity. I used to play it a lot on a Mac. I would still love to play it. But not this releaes, not this version. The tools and interface are clunky in the best situation. That's the nicest thing I can say about it. Here's this great game, but you ... just ... can't ... quite ... access it. The interface has a mind of its own, which bears little resemblance to what you want to do (let alone any kind of reality-sim). For example, why, on a completely flat and empty plain, can a cloverleaf only be placed at a 45 degree angle to the grid? Why can't I decide for myself how I want to place it?You end up building a highway, destroy it, build it again .... and so on until you get something vaguley like what you were after. Or your budget runs out.There it is, just out of reach, the fun game I used to play. It is an exercise in extreme frustration. I am going to delete this game and hope I can erase it from my memory.

												Well its an old game now but what makes it truly obselete and any game that follows this pattern of city building simulator is its style of civic engineering is obselete. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												This game is Mr. Turtle approved.A classic city builder, indepth but not boring or hard to grasp in the least.You have disasters which you can control, the game only generates fires as its natural disasters leaving it all up to you to level the city.You have three zones Residential, Commercial, and Industrial. There is argriculture but that's just another industrial zone.So you can make a little farming community if you wish. Or a bustling metropolis.You manage water, electricity, and trash.You may trade with a neighbor in the region.However all the cities in the region are built by you.You can generate simple regions and edit the terrain via each section of the entire map. So click a tile, load in, mess with the terrain if you please and then you get down to business and enter Mayor mode.Gone are your god-like powers... sure.... It's a fun game and a must have for those who like to build cities.

												To all residents of BCIVille:It has come to my attention that a number of you have filed complaints regarding increasing numbers of traffic collisions, crimes and pollution. Rest assured, as mayor I am hard at work on a plan to solve all of our great city's problems at the same time. I cannot say too much right now as it's still in the planning phase, but the general idea of the BCIVille Renewal Project '14 includes an aggressive strategy of tax breaks, industry subsidies and strategic nuclear strikes in the worst areas of the city. As well I'm considering the possibility of using new, exotic materials to simplify our existing infrastructure in order to save our public works departments millions of dollars per year in materials compared to what we've been doing until now. I've discussed the effectiveness of this plan with my advisors and a number of constituents and they all agree: this will work. According to official reports from the BCIVille Department of Quite Reliable Statistics, we should expect to see a 58% increase in cromulence by the year 2016.I understand some of you may have questions or concerns, and believe me, I need your input as citizens to perfect BCIVille for all of us. If you want to volunteer, please address your opinions to the following mailing address, located conveniently next to our city's landfill:BCIVille Municipal Feedback Department4200 West Accidental Ave. Building 4APO Box 810BCIVille, SimNation 66986Thank you for your attention.Sincerely,Office of Most Honorable Mayor arbayer2BCIVille City Hall

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I have 113 hours on record. I still have no idea how half of the transportation in the game should be utilized. Is that bad? No, the game just sucks you in so much into managing your town, keeping up on money, trying to get those skyscrapers going, making sure your roads don't suck, that you may overlook some of the stuff because of how much fun you are having making your town EFFICIENT. You know you can do better than your current towns crumbling economy? Prove it! You think having a military contract will help? SCREW YOU BUDDY CRIMERATE IS UP FROM HAVING MILITARY DO WHAT THEY WANT THE DON'T NEED NO MAN. Take it slow, watch what you pay people, keep it in the green and keep developing and moving on education because if you stop too soon, your maintenance gets costly, you'll start running into that red, and one last tip, make sure you have a good amount of water, old buildings burn fast!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Ok, so you know how good those freshly baked choc chip cookies from your grandma are, ey? Well this game is that good. Actually no, it's better! (Yes I just went there). If city building is your thing, in this case it's mine, this is the game for you! The amount of gameplay you can experience is amazing, and you can expand your game so much with mods made by communities til this day! I have played this game for over 400 hours, which is cool and kind of scary at the same time. I'd call myself a SimCity veteran even though I'm just 17.Besides all of that, this game is worth every penny and has the best replay value of all the games in my library. Try it!Stay cool dudesAJ

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												It's 99% fantastic on my Win7 PC, ramps up at a good pace, classic play, just enough 'simulation' to make me believe I'm controlling hundreds of thousands of little folks and getting them to build bigger and better buildings, and that the parks I place around town really do suck up the pollution nearby.There's an occasional freeze/bug where I have to fire up Task Manager and put it in its place, but this very rare, and virtually never for a city I've had going for a while.  An acceptable level of downtime for something I keep running alongside while I do my work.If you find it on a holiday sale for, oh, $4.99, I'd say I've gotten more enjoyment out of this than a venti mocha from that one infamous green and white coffee shop franchise.  I'd for sure recommend this to any one who got burned by SimCity5 :)

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												This game is Mr. Turtle approved.A classic city builder, indepth but not boring or hard to grasp in the least.You have disasters which you can control, the game only generates fires as its natural disasters leaving it all up to you to level the city.You have three zones Residential, Commercial, and Industrial. There is argriculture but that's just another industrial zone.So you can make a little farming community if you wish. Or a bustling metropolis.You manage water, electricity, and trash.You may trade with a neighbor in the region.However all the cities in the region are built by you.You can generate simple regions and edit the terrain via each section of the entire map. So click a tile, load in, mess with the terrain if you please and then you get down to business and enter Mayor mode.Gone are your god-like powers... sure.... It's a fun game and a must have for those who like to build cities.

												SimCity 4 is a fun game.  If you played simcity2000 this is the perfect successor to that game.  Pipes are simplified, water is easy and plentiful.  Power is generally easy to manage as are most the cities systems.  I didn't HAVE to cheat to win this game or even to play it the way I wanted to.  The cities seem to adapt better no matter how poorly you place zones.  I love this game.However....  Numerous crash issues, memory leak issues, Huge cities seem to bog down the game in ways you wouldn't expect.  (water being there then not there then there in pipes, leading to rallies about not having water then they do) My pc is far an away powerful enough to run this game, a beast machine when this game was made new. Still this game does not always work.  I would say this game is worth playing, toying around with despite it's many bad programming faults. Just be aware and save often.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												SimCity 4, the last Maxis SimCity, remains the best of its genre to this day. Although it lacks the speculative technology of SimCity 2000 or the beautiful slit-scan rendering of the (perhaps unfairly infamous) 2013 revision, SC4 is thorough and rigorous in its realism and level of simulated detail. For example, to check the operation of the simulation at the individual level, you can create and follow sims (and their dynasties) as they travel around from home to work and back, finding jobs appropriate to their social class/level of education, to test your city's transportation grid down to the individual level of detail.This Deluxe Edition comes with the Rush Hour expansion which adds even more detail and control options to transportation simulation. The only significant drawback is that, like previous SimCities, roads cannot truly bend or angle properly; cities consequently must be laid out more or less in a grid pattern. Of course, as Atlanta just demonstrated in Half-Inchopocalypse 2014, there are excellent reasons to avoid curving and angling roads all over the place in city planning, so this is a "feature" that you most likely won't miss.

												If you like these kind of games (strategy, economy, building the entire city, even the transports), you are late, GET THIS GAME NOW!!!IT'S ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME. -Hundreds of hours of play!-It can even run on a netbook (you can hack the resolution, google it), and it doesn't lag!-Good replayability!-The graphics aged really well, i think they still look pretty much perfect, they don't have to be better. 												I got a bug for this series since playing Sim City on the SNES way back. Then again, maybe it wasn't a bug as I never played any of the games apart from the SNES version and this, but I trusted the general angle of the reviews.In short, a great game that's ages superbly. You can really soak up the hours once you get a city going and you have massive control. The 'tutorial' cities give you breathing room and you're bound to learn from your mistakes quickly when you get caught in the traps of over/under development of certain of your cities' aspects.I'm quite rubbish at the game, but that doesn't stop it being one of the most absorbing games I've ever played (in that sense, I'd put it there with the likes of Morrowind, Zelda, FFVII, Shenmue - games that utterly took hold of me!)

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Still the city simulator after a decadeFirst, this is a really complex game, similar to how running an actual city is really complex. If you don't like managing a lot of detail, then this game isn't for you. There are a lot of zones, utilities, civic structures, and transportation systems to build. It's a bit overwhelming at first, so make sure to go through the tutorials and start small (e.g., low-density zones, no education system, no hospitals, and no water system). While the complexity makes it a bit hard to get into SC4, it's the same thing that's missing in SimCity Societies and SimCity (2013).Second, unless you're playing on a Mac which gets the updated port by Aspyr, you'll have some technical problems to deal with. Basically, you have to add command line parameters to tell the game to use only one of your CPU's cores and to use resolutions that didn't exist when SC4 was released (like 1920x1080). Search the forums for details on recommended parameters. Once you've gotten that figured out, you might want to fiddle a bit with the graphics options (I think I reduced the shading/shadow effects to minimum). With this sorted out, the game runs pretty smoothly for me and only crashes every few hours on average. Save often to be safe. I have no idea if Aspyr's planning to release a Windows version of their Mac version, but when/if they do, these technical problems should pretty much disappear.Third, there are some issues with game mechanics that make it hard to build big regions without mods. While you can do a lot without adding mods, I strongly recommend using the Network Addon Mod (NAM) and Colossus Addon Mod (CAM), at least after you reach the point where things stop working correctly. Even if you don't enable any of the NAM's custom transportation systems, it's worth it for the improved traffic simulator alone. There are lots of mods for fixing other things and adding pretty much everything, so use your favorite search engine and explore. There's still a really active modding community after a decade.Overall, SimCity 4 is a great game once you put in the time to learn it and work around the technical issues. It has what's missing in the newer SimCity games and doesn't force you to be constantly online. It would be really awesome if Aspyr ports their Mac port to Windows (and Linux!), fixing all the technical issues. Until then, I recommend waiting for this game to go on sale before buying it here. I got it for $5 in early 2014 to replace my CD copy that finally broke.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												It has been a long time since I wanted to get a SimCity game past Classic, so when I saw SimCity 2013. I got it. Too many problems, so I returned it. Then I saw this one on Steam, so I got it, hoping that it'd at least be able to run smoothly. I was not disappointed.To me, it took a while to adjust to the new things that needed to be managed (like supplying water and spamming the city with parks and trees and etc.) compared to SimCity Classic. Now, I can say that I'm doing a decent job running a city.Lots of thinking and planning is involved to make a good city. It takes some time to get to that but it's rewarding once you're there. Some of the guides found online can help a lot.One of the only things that I dislike about this game is the U-Drive it mode. I've had instances where cars would spawn where I'm at and automatically wreck the car I'm driving. There are other times where I'd drive adjacent to the edge/border of the city, and the game would think that I "left" the city and fail me. Other than that, everything else about the game is pretty solid.At the end, I'm happy to say that I'm happy with this buy. :D If you get it, I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!

												The best city building game so far,with fantastic graphics and endless possibilities! Its not a game for everyone,its pretty challenging,but once you figure out how to make money,and you see your city grow,its a fantastic feeling! For mere 5 euros you can become a mayor of your dream city! And with the Rush Hour expansion,you can fly planes and helicopters over your city,you can roam the streets in a car,tank,or even an icecream van-yes, an ICE CREAM VAN! A must buy for every fan of strategy games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												If you like these kind of games (strategy, economy, building the entire city, even the transports), you are late, GET THIS GAME NOW!!!IT'S ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME. -Hundreds of hours of play!-It can even run on a netbook (you can hack the resolution, google it), and it doesn't lag!-Good replayability!-The graphics aged really well, i think they still look pretty much perfect, they don't have to be better. (i don't care about graphics in fact, but in this case, even if i cared, it aged well!)-Thousands of mods and buildings that you can download, so these can make your games longer, better and more replayable!-The possibilities are huge, you could make a city in the desert, in the mountains, whatever biome, and if you don't like it, you can modify the land in any way you want.-The driving missions are sometimes hard, but it's awesome to drive in your own city, the roads you made. And it also reflects the traffic load in your city.-The transports! There's almost anything: planes, trains, ferry, and more. And each one has its missions, and loads of vehicles.So yeah, i'm forgetting stuff. I love this game, i played it even more on my pirated version, but i finally bought it, it is totally worth it, and you can trust a stranger for once ;)

												I purchased this on Steam last week, fully expecting it to be as good as the CD version I had on a Windows XP machine last year. I enjoyed many hours of fun and wanted to see how my Monster gaming computer would handle it. I was really bumded when it kept crashing my computer before I could create a city. Or region. Froze it up several times. Then I found out through forums that SimCity Deluxe can't be played on a computer that has AMD video cards or Crossfired cards.Wish I had found this out BEFORE i purchased and downloaded it. There should be a disclaimer that tells us when games won't work on our computers. So I got a refund. Too bad. I really liked SimCity.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												How many hours, no, days of my life have not gone into this game? I don't know, but it was a lot. SimCity 4 still is the best city planning simulator ever made. It strikes just the right balance between (micro) management and sheer fun. Most remarkable about the game is that it has this great flow: at times soothing and calm, then frantic and stressing. The jazzy/atmospheric music and the pastel colours all help in creating this atmospheric sense of timelessness and universality as you are working on your city. The soundscape of cars, planes, animals, accidents all help in letting your city come to life. Of course there are faults to be found and after hundreds of hours of gameplay the game's options and diversity have been all but exhausted. City building will then no longer provide a challenge, even on hard mode. But these points are just nitpicking because there was so much fun to be had. So much wonderful creations to be engineered. SimCity 4 is a great game that I still recommend anyone to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Running low on funds to run your city?  You can do missions for the good guys or the bad guys and everything will be fine...or will it?   Go from building the city to playing one of the citizens real quick and back again.  But don't mess up too often or it could bankrupt the whole town.Has some bugs and is real old tech.  Still it is lots of fun.Simcity online should have been more like this game.Oh and another thing....the theme music for this game is Legendary.....boom boom boom boom, boom boom boom boom....etc....this music makes everyone instantly cooler just for listening.Oh and one more thing....you can actually connect your cities with actual roads and they benefit from the traffic and....well you gotta see it for yourself....the more cities you play the more your cities benefit.   Your new cities will start with any roads from adjacent cities that you've already created/played.  Try to find that in one of the newer city building games.  When you start a new one you can actually see your other city's connecting road when you start out.  Awesome feature.

Do bears like honey? Duh.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												SimCity 4 Deluxe Edition gives a new feel to the SimCity series as well as offering a fun and new driving system. SC4DE, along with its predecessors, allows you to take full control of a plot of land to design your dream city. You can create world famous iconic buildings such as the Hollywood sign, London Tower, the Empire State Building, and many more! Even though you have this large amount of freedom, you also are presented the challenge of maintaining balance and order in your city. Overall this game is worth your money, mainly because it was made before EA became thieving... umm..."fatherless" people... Definitely pick it up when you have the chance.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												This is a very very good city builder with lots of mod-support. Tips and tricks:1: Make sure to play the game slowly in the beginning, always try to keep a bit of profit.2: Your sims do NOT need a firestaiton, policestation nor a hospital early in the game. theese are used mostly to make your sims more productive and making sure higher income citizens come to your city. if you put them in too early then it will leave your income well below red.3: Why just one city? Building alot of cities and connecting them with rails, highways, ferry routes and so on is very important for the growth of not just your city but for your entire region. In this game building a verý succesfull city whitout neighbouring cities will be super hard of not down right impossible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2015
												I can remember how excited I was to get SC4 Deluxe back when it first came out ...(and I actually did get a good laugh out of 'warped regions' - the improper bit-map config files that appeared to create overlapping cities)--- and I actually had years of play time with this game, before it came to Steam ------ not to mention the oversized plug-in folder, now on it's very own usb drive ---... now it is available on Steam!A few pet peeves with this one: The SC4 terraforming tools were the new 'area effect' ones, NOT an improvement in my opinion (as an 'addition to' would have been nifty - yes, but as a 'complete replacement' ... there were times I would have liked to have the old tile-by-tile tools ... - no); Due to the dev's not understanding that elevated (already having a 'bridge' structure) transit doesn't need to use a BRIDGE to cross 'ground/surface water' (thus creating visual issues resulting from requiring a bridge to cross ANY water (in previous versions of SimCity) neither 'ground/surface water' nor hydroelectric power plants were available in SC4; The near impossible requirements to get a bridge that didn't have water somewhere below it; The way bridges were implemented didn't allow for above ground transit crossing underneath one - regardless of how much difference in elevation there might be; And Electronic Arts only officially released one (of several possible) expansion packages.The (imo) noteworthy redeeming features include: The ability for water craft (ferries, freight and leisure) to make it under a sufficiently high bridge; The stubs, in a neighbor city, that an intercity connection made - of whatever ... transit, utility, etc ... you chose to establish. The (new - for that time) 'modding' tools; As I remember it, the first SimCity to have a 64-bit version; And the bump up in available map sizes (64x64, 128x128, and -NEW- 256x256).All said - IMO - the best city simulater I have seen.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												At a healthy eleven years old SimCity 4 may very well be the last great Maxis game. The replayability of this game is huge, trying to develop different cities against new challenges or even planning entire regions (which can take dozens, even hundreds of hours). Then, when all is said and done, knock out a few hours in sandbox mode by displaying your almighty wrath with earthquakes, fires, alien invasions, and giant robot attacks. Unlike its decendent, SimCity, this game does not have an always-online component (nor does it have any online play) and is a complete package game.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Fun game made awesome by the great modding community. I love to sand box it to design cities and see how it pans out. Some game mechanics are dumb. The little sim jerks hate having to commute to work at all and you can't always connect roads for unappearant reasons. And making corners on elevated highways? God help us all. I would strangle each and every one of the sim advisers. But I really like sandbox builder games. I have a unreasonable amount of time put into Black & White 2 because BUILDINGS YOThe cheats are hilariously offensive. "weakness pays" and "You don't deserve it". Ha! But weakness pays only spews 1k which is pretty useless unless you are just trying to survive the first part of the game. Get the BSE Funding mod if you like to just build to your hearts content like I do. but seriously. This game is kinda brutal without it. The only way to make a successful city is connected to the ruins of your failed cities. super slow to get money during any part of the game. Sims throw FITS if you raise taxes and are always demanding more stuff. Any amount of industrial creates bad pollution but your sims demand it so you have to scatter it thinly throughout the city and next to parks and they still demand more. Proper zoning is very nit picky. Farms create crazy water pollution. How do you even train it is useless build subways. Tolls can only be placed on avenues and highways and congests traffic badly. I'm not really into games that make me scream from frustration, that's my husband's gig. But for some reason the frustrating aspects of this game just challenge and entice me to play more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Still the city simulator after a decadeFirst, this is a really complex game, similar to how running an actual city is really complex. If you don't like managing a lot of detail, then this game isn't for you. There are a lot of zones, utilities, civic structures, and transportation systems to build. It's a bit overwhelming at first, so make sure to go through the tutorials and start small (e.g., low-density zones, no education system, no hospitals, and no water system). While the complexity makes it a bit hard to get into SC4, it's the same thing that's missing in SimCity Societies and SimCity (2013).Second, unless you're playing on a Mac which gets the updated port by Aspyr, you'll have some technical problems to deal with. Basically, you have to add command line parameters to tell the game to use only one of your CPU's cores and to use resolutions that didn't exist when SC4 was released (like 1920x1080). Search the forums for details on recommended parameters. Once you've gotten that figured out, you might want to fiddle a bit with the graphics options (I think I reduced the shading/shadow effects to minimum). With this sorted out, the game runs pretty smoothly for me and only crashes every few hours on average. Save often to be safe. I have no idea if Aspyr's planning to release a Windows version of their Mac version, but when/if they do, these technical problems should pretty much disappear.Third, there are some issues with game mechanics that make it hard to build big regions without mods. While you can do a lot without adding mods, I strongly recommend using the Network Addon Mod (NAM) and Colossus Addon Mod (CAM), at least after you reach the point where things stop working correctly. Even if you don't enable any of the NAM's custom transportation systems, it's worth it for the improved traffic simulator alone. There are lots of mods for fixing other things and adding pretty much everything, so use your favorite search engine and explore. There's still a really active modding community after a decade.Overall, SimCity 4 is a great game once you put in the time to learn it and work around the technical issues. It has what's missing in the newer SimCity games and doesn't force you to be constantly online. It would be really awesome if Aspyr ports their Mac port to Windows (and Linux!), fixing all the technical issues. Until then, I recommend waiting for this game to go on sale before buying it here. I got it for $5 in early 2014 to replace my CD copy that finally broke.

This feature gives it strong replayability as you always want to build new ones to make your first ones better, and thus retrurn to periodicaly. Unlike SimCity 5 - this game is worth its money.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Sim City 4: The game to buy when you were disapointed with the latest edition to the Sim City Franchise.Sim City has been a game that I have grown up with, and will always hold a special place in my heart for. While the graphics are certaintly not up to todays standards, the game offers hours upon hours of fun and relaxation. In the game, you take on the role of the mayor of a brand new city. You have to then design and build this empty plot of land into a large, and busy city. The game is nice because it offers fun and enjoyment to all skill levels. For example, one could simply just build to build, or you could go into such minute details about your city, and try fixing all of the problems. I have poured many hours into this game, and highly recomend it.But as a warning: The game does not support 1920 x 1080 res, and will occasionally crash (only crashed on my laptop, works fine on my tower).

Posted: January 13, 2014
												I got a bug for this series since playing Sim City on the SNES way back. Then again, maybe it wasn't a bug as I never played any of the games apart from the SNES version and this, but I trusted the general angle of the reviews.In short, a great game that's ages superbly. You can really soak up the hours once you get a city going and you have massive control. The 'tutorial' cities give you breathing room and you're bound to learn from your mistakes quickly when you get caught in the traps of over/under development of certain of your cities' aspects.I'm quite rubbish at the game, but that doesn't stop it being one of the most absorbing games I've ever played (in that sense, I'd put it there with the likes of Morrowind, Zelda, FFVII, Shenmue - games that utterly took hold of me!)

												It's 99% fantastic on my Win7 PC, ramps up at a good pace, classic play, just enough 'simulation' to make me believe I'm controlling hundreds of thousands of little folks and getting them to build bigger and better buildings, and that the parks I place around town really do suck up the pollution nearby.There's an occasional freeze/bug where I have to fire up Task Manager and put it in its place, but this very rare, and virtually never for a city I've had going for a while.  An acceptable level of downtime for something I keep running alongside while I do my work.If you find it on a holiday sale for, oh, $4.99, I'd say I've gotten more enjoyment out of this than a venti mocha from that one infamous green and white coffee shop franchise.  I'd for sure recommend this to any one who got burned by SimCity5 :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I'm not as familiar as some might be with the Sim City series. The last one I played was on the SNES and compared to SC4 it definitely has it's differences. Even after 18 years of not playing, it was easy to get back into Sim City after playing through the tutorials. Being able to setup a region and build cities in different sections all across it is cool. Also liked that I can add mountains, valleys, rivers, lakes etc.. and customize the regions to my liking. The Rush hour expansion is a nice addition so I can control what kind of transportation I want in my cities and provides an extra challenge to building my cities. I've only put in a couple of sessions and I know there are so many features in this game I haven't touched on.I would tell anyone who is looking for a strategy/simulation game then this one should be considered. I was very iffy about the newest Sim City which is why I picked this one up. You don't have to worry about being online to play the game and works well with current operating systems. If you are interested in getting a start into Sim City games then I would say start here.

												SimCity 4 is the king of the City builders. While it does have its glitches here and there, they are minor once you get them ironed out. Its best feature by far is the ability to campaign map and build a massive connected metropolitan area of multiple cities. This feature gives it strong replayability as you always want to build new ones to make your first ones better, and thus retrurn to periodicaly. Unlike SimCity 5 - this game is worth its money.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												This is a Fantastic City building and Management sim. I Highly reccomend. You can play it with a degree in city design and still have as much fun as someone who knows f-all about cities. I reccommend playing with the Network Acess Mod with adds roads and improves the pathfinding of the AI, so unemployment due to commute is a thing of the past. I recomend this game as much as i would reccomend Civilzation 4 or 5. The graphics aren't great compared to Battlefeild 4 or GTA V but hey you can tell a building is a building. Also the detail is good you can zoom right in and see your little sims playing about at the school or families going out for a picnic at the Park. So what rating do give this game? A solid 9. Pretty high with 10 being my favourite game of all time. So even though i have NOWHERE near enough experience as some what i have is still enough to merit this as a great game. to me it is comperable to some AAA games. So all in all if your gonna grab a simulator make it this one. heres a more thourough run down of RatingGraphics: 4/5 Sound:5/5( i could listen all day)Custamisation: 3/5 (no micromanaging so if you a fan of that be aware) Fun: 4/5Highly Reccomend

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Hard, but that doesn't mean not good.while simcity 3000 will remain my favorite for the rest of the conceivable future, 4 has a certain charm and depth of mechanics that makes me itch for more.the budgeting system has been overhauled allowing for much, much more customization and indepth management of your city's utitlities, waste management, and tax revenue. whereas in 3000 you could only manage RCI taxes as a sort of umbrella for each type, in 4 you can raise and lower taxes based on the pay bracket (for commercial and residential) or the subtype (industrial, separated into agricultural, dirty industry, clean industry and high tech industry). this management allows you to pinpoint taxes where you want them, potentially driving out a class of residents or commerce, or inviting in the same.the zoning rules have changed dramatically. whereas in 3000 you simply designate a plot of land and let the sims do the rest, in 4 each zoned lot has a facing and transportation/utilities needs that have to be met before the lot will develop. designating a large area will automatically add roads so that you don't have to micromanage each lot's transportation needs for the most part.on the topic of transportation, roads in general have recieved an overhaul, splitting them into four classes of road, with separate capacities for travel: streets, traditional roads, avenues and highways. while the avenue, the highway, and of couse the road were availabe in 3000, the avenue was constructed by putting two roads together, and the highway was bank-breakingly overpriced. the newest addition, the street, is a low capacity form of transport that requires very little maintenance.coming back to utility management, each utility building (water pumps, power plants, landfills) has a seperate funding slider that can be adjusted to change the output or intake of the facility in question. such a mechanic can be used to set power systems into standby, or to limit usage of over-producing plants; all very useful for a city that has just begun.the region system is where this game really shines, however. the ability to create dozens of cities and have them all work together is simply incredible.in short, simcity 4 is a very deep, very complicated game, but the rewards are very high. the amount of fun I've had here despite losing is roughly .75 times what I've had in 3000, which is saying something considering how much I've loved 3000.buy it. and a pocket calculator, maybe a budgeting clipboard

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Sim City 4: The game to buy when you were disapointed with the latest edition to the Sim City Franchise.Sim City has been a game that I have grown up with, and will always hold a special place in my heart for. While the graphics are certaintly not up to todays standards, the game offers hours upon hours of fun and relaxation. In the game, you take on the role of the mayor of a brand new city. You have to then design and build this empty plot of land into a large, and busy city. The game is nice because it offers fun and enjoyment to all skill levels. For example, one could simply just build to build, or you could go into such minute details about your city, and try fixing all of the problems. I have poured many hours into this game, and highly recomend it.But as a warning: The game does not support 1920 x 1080 res, and will occasionally crash (only crashed on my laptop, works fine on my tower).

Posted: August 25, 2014
												Now I've paid the ten years' debt that I owed Maxis.A decade ago,a friend of mine gave me a pirate CD includes several gamesAnd I've found this game that occupied most of childhood memories of playing games.I was obsessed with it.I played it day and night,I would never be tired of playing this game.At first,I didn't even know how to designate zones,just knew how to place a bunch of fancy buildings and set disasters.But I could also play for a long time with lots of joy.After that I learnt how to designate areas,make citizens(SIMs) happier and attract the rich,I understood this game couldn't just be a simple game,there must be many things and surprises to research and discover.SimCity 4 moved me so much. In this game,you are an omnipotent mayor,developing your ideal city.Planning,construction,expansion,management,these are the main circulation patterns of this game.There are unlimited challenge,creation and innovation.2D graphics are pretty and the details are awesome.Background musics are pleasant and will never get tired of hearing.You can feel that you are really running the city of yours.A great many different mods and plugins can make players have more contents to enjoy.Some said SC series are lack of playability,also some said it's bored,without passion,won't be played for a half hour.I just wanna say,you are just far from dectecting the essence of this game:)

But that's okay because I just destroyed the whole city with earthquakes.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2011
												"On Exactitude in Sim City," ... "In that game, the art of mapping attained such perfection that the map of a single city occupied the entirety of a zone, and the map of the region, the entirety of a city. In time, those unconscionable maps no longer satisfied, and the modding community struck a map of a region whose size was that of the region, and which coincided point for point with it. The following gaming generation, who were not so fond of the study of mapping as their forebears had been, saw that that vast map was useless, and not without some pitilessness was it, that they delivered it up to the inclemencies of incompatible versions. In the abandoned websites, still today, there are corrupted files of that map, inhabited by broken links and bugs; in all the Internet there is no other relic of the disciplines of geography." - Suárez Miranda, Viajes de jugadores prudentes, Libro IV,Cap. XLV, Lerida, 1658. (Apologies to Jorge Luis Borges)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I'm not sure any Sim game can beat the experience of the original, which most of us came across on a computer in study hall in our middle or high school. It isn't about features, graphics or customization - just one of those times when the first iteration of a game is the most enjoyable, no matter how vast the improvements since then.I commend SC4 for even coming CLOSE to that experience. Despite the "it's not the original" feeling I do find myself getting wrapped up in creating my perfect city. This game has everything you'd want out of a city builder, complete with a street view and dispatching fire trucks. Graphically it's pretty good. It's not awe-inspiring or offputting, just good enough to not be a distraction - which is exactly the pocket a game like this should fit into. After all, there are plenty of games to be visually struck by, that just isn't the point of a city builder. Options and control are far more important, and it exceeds expectations in leaps and bounds.One thing I always wished was possible was differing time periods - being able to make a town with a 60's feel, or the Old West - presenting a lot of different problems, using different buildings, etc. I watch Back to the Future a lot (a lot!) so perhaps I'm alone in that. Either way, SC4 is moddable.. so if you're good at that kinda thing you might be able to create an even better experience for yourself.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I must have bought this game at least 3 times over the years, having worn out old disc copies before picking it up here on Steam.Pretty much everything that is wrong with the new SimCity was right in SimCity 4, which was the culmination of over a decade of evolution through the original SimCity, SimCity 2000 and SimCity 3000. A decade further on, there is still a strong community around the game, and plenty of mods available to change everything from the appearance of water to the way the entire highway system works.If you want to build a sprawling metropolis or a rural country region, this is certainly the game to go with. Only Cities Skylines has come close since.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												SimCity 4 is a game that I spent a lot of time with in my early 20s. It had its fair share of bugs when it was first released and I remember a lot of frustration on forums early on. Crashes were frequent and the performance was not great despite having hardware more than capable of handling it. These many years later, the game runs much more smoothly than it ever did and it's a joy to go back and play. It's complex without being irritating (I will never understand where to put bus stations to get them to work properly, though). I've played SimCity since the first game was released in the late 80s (I played it in the early 90s), and SC4 ranks high on my list - perhaps below SC2000, but slightly higher than SC3000. The beauty of SC4 is the size of the maps, the inclusion of regions and the varied building style. The customisation of terrain is also the most advanced of all of the SimCities (in the latest one, terrain editing is sadly lacking). The latest SimCity is not worthy of the name and this represents the last of the good ones. If you're wanting a more recent city builder, consider Cities Skylines.
